sources.query: count(count(ts(telegraf.exec.fdbcli-memory.cluster.processes.46*, tag="${mirror}" and source="*-db1-*" and excluded=False), address))
sources.name: New Query

sources.query: count(count(ts(telegraf.exec.fdbcli.cluster.processes.45*, tag="${mirror}" and source="*-db1-*" and excluded=False), address))
sources.name: New Query

charts.description:
This is critical and requires immediate action or we'll start queuing points. Failover immediately if this is the serving side. 

To clear, issue the following fdbcli commands:
clear \x02__cluster_fingerprint__\x00
charts.name: FDB SSD Fingerprint

charts.description:
This is critical and requires immediate action or we'll start queuing points. Failover immediately if this is the serving side. 

To clear, issue the following fdbcli commands:
clear \x02__cluster_fingerprint__\x00
charts.name: FDB MEM Fingerprint
MEM Durable Bytes Vs. Input By Process

sources.query: ts(fdb.trace.46*.memory and not fdb.trace.465*.memory, tag="${mirror}" and source=${dbhost})
sources.name: Memory

charts.description: Processes reach a steady state where memory fluctuates very little, while FDB is healing though you can see processes memory growing.  This can help identify which processes are still healing without having to know which exact DB is undergoing the healing.
charts.name: MEM Transaction Proc Healing

charts.description: Pegged processes can identify a process that is not particularly behaving properly within the cluster and degrading the current state of the cluster.  Pegged processes can be killed with kill -9 or via the /opt/wavefront/repo/tools/killFdbProcesses.sh script
charts.name: Pegged CPU Processes

charts.description: File sizes represented here are an indication of the maximum log file size on disk for any given node.  If file sizes exceed the storage_memory configuration for a cluster (typically 3GiB) this can cause a cluster to become stuck and unable to recover.

sources.query: rawmax(ts(telegraf.filestat.size.bytes, tag="${mirror}" and source=${dbhost} and file="/mnt/mem1/*"), sources)
sources.name: New Query

sources.query: sum(taggify(ts(telegraf.filestat.size.bytes, tag="${mirror}" and source=${dbhost} and (file="/mnt/mem1/*" or file="/mnt/tlogs1/*")), tagk, "file", "port", 3, "/"), sources, port)
sources.name: file sizes (green)

charts.name: Mem Transaction Procs Filesize
SSD Durable Bytes Vs. Input By Process

sources.query: ts(fdb.trace.45*.memory and not fdb.trace.455*.memory and not fdb.trace.456*.memory, tag="${mirror}" and source=${dbhost})
sources.name: Memory

charts.description: Processes reach a steady state where memory fluctuates very little, while FDB is healing though you can see processes memory growing.  This can help identify which processes are still healing without having to know which exact DB is undergoing the healing.
charts.name: SSD Transaction Proc Healing

sources.query: ts(fdb.trace.455*.cpu_seconds or fdb.trace.456*.cpu_seconds, tag="${mirror}" and source=${dbhost})
sources.name: CPU Seconds

charts.description:
TIME_WAIT indicates that local endpoint (this side) has closed the connection. The connection is being kept around so that any delayed packets can be matched to the connection and handled appropriately.

db1 will typically always be higher than the rest 

Exceptionally high wait times across multiple DBs can identify significant network latencies, during outages we should attempt to exclude or stop/start clusters to return wait times to normal levels.

sources.query: ts(telegraf.netstat.tcp.time.wait, tag=${mirror} and role=db and source=${dbhost})
sources.name: time_wait

charts.name: TCP TIME_WAIT

sources.query: topk(100, 100-max(ts(telegraf.cpu.usage.idle, tag="${mirror}" and role=db and source=${dbhost} and not cpu=cpu-total), sources, cpu))
sources.name: New Query

sources.query: 100-ts(telegraf.cpu.usage.idle, tag=${mirror} and role=db and cpu=cpu-total and source=${dbhost})
sources.name: CPU Utilization

sources.query: ts(telegraf.mem.used.percent, tag=${mirror} and role=db and source=${dbhost})
sources.name: % mem used

charts.description: If you need to upsize the transaction procs this dashboard provides you with how much headroom per proc is available - if there is less than 3G per proc this should not be done as we are oversubscribed on the node.

sources.query: max(ts(telegraf.mem.free, tag=${mirror} and role=db and source=${dbhost}), sources)
sources.name: Free Mem

sources.query: count(ts(fdb.trace.46*.role.worker, tag=${mirror} and tag=db and source=${dbhost}), sources)
sources.name: trans procs

charts.name: Proc Upsize Headroom

sources.query: ts("aws.ebs.volumewriteops.sum", tag=${mirror} and not tag=eval and tag=db and source=${dbhost})
sources.name: writeops

sources.query: ts("aws.ebs.volumereadops.sum", tag=${mirror} and not tag=eval and tag=db and source=${dbhost})
sources.name: readops

sources.query: rate(ts(telegraf.diskio.reads, tag=${mirror} and not tag=eval and tag=db and source=${dbhost} and name="dm-*"))
sources.name: telegraf-readbytes

sources.query: rate(ts(telegraf.diskio.writes, tag=${mirror} and not tag=eval and tag=db and source=${dbhost} and name="dm-*"))
sources.name: telegraf-writebytes

sources.query: rate(ts(telegraf.diskio.reads, tag=${mirror} and not tag=eval and tag=db and source=${dbhost} and (name="xvdc" or name="xvdb" or name="nvme*"or name="*eiocache")))
sources.name: telegraf-readbytes

sources.query: rate(ts(telegraf.diskio.writes, tag=${mirror} and not tag=eval and tag=db and source=${dbhost} and (name="xvdc" or name="xvdb" or name="nvme*")))
sources.name: telegraf-writebytes

sources.query: ts(telegraf.diskio.iops.in.progress, tag=${mirror} and not tag=eval and tag=db and source=${dbhost} and (name="xvdb" or name="nvme*"))
sources.name: SSD/NVME

sources.query: ts(telegraf.diskio.iops.in.progress, tag=${mirror} and not tag=eval and tag=db and source=${dbhost} and name="dm-*")
sources.name: LVM Raid

sources.query: ts(aws.ebs.burstbalance, tag=${mirror} and not tag=eval and tag=db)
sources.name: Burst Balance

sources.query: ts("aws.ebs.volumewriteops.sum", tag=${mirror} and not tag=eval and tag=db and source=${dbhost})
sources.name: writeops

sources.query: ts("aws.ebs.volumereadops.sum", tag=${mirror} and not tag=eval and tag=db and source=${dbhost})
sources.name: readops

sources.query: rate(ts(telegraf.diskio.reads, tag=${mirror} and not tag=eval and tag=db and source=${dbhost} and name="dm-*"))
sources.name: telegraf-readio

sources.query: rate(ts(telegraf.diskio.writes, tag=${mirror} and not tag=eval and tag=db and source=${dbhost} and name="dm-*"))
sources.name: telegraf-writeio

sources.query: rate(ts(telegraf.diskio.reads, tag=${mirror} and not tag=eval and tag=db and source=${dbhost} and not (name="xvdc" or name="xvdb" or name="nvme*" or name=dm-*)))
sources.name: telegraf-readio

sources.query: rate(ts(telegraf.diskio.writes, tag=${mirror} and not tag=eval and tag=db and source=${dbhost} and not (name="xvdc" or name="xvdb" or name="nvme*" or name=dm-*)))
sources.name: telegraf-writeio

sources.query: rate(ts(telegraf.diskio.reads, tag=${mirror} and not tag=eval and tag=db and source=${dbhost} and (name="xvdc" or name="xvdb" or name="nvme*")))
sources.name: telegraf-readio

sources.query: rate(ts(telegraf.diskio.writes, tag=${mirror} and not tag=eval and tag=db and source=${dbhost} and (name="xvdc" or name="xvdb" or name="nvme*")))
sources.name: telegraf-writeio

sources.query: rate(ts(telegraf.diskio.reads, tag=${mirror} and not tag=eval and tag=db and source=${dbhost} and not (name='xvdl' or name='xvda*' or name="xvdc" or name="xvdb" or name="nvme*" or name=dm-*)))
sources.name: telegraf-readio

sources.query: rate(ts(telegraf.diskio.writes, tag=${mirror} and not tag=eval and tag=db and source=${dbhost} and not (name='xvdl' or name='xvda*' or name="xvdc" or name="xvdb" or name="nvme*" or name=dm-*)))
sources.name: telegraf-writeio

sources.query: rate(ts(telegraf.diskio.reads, tag=${mirror} and not tag=eval and tag=db and source=${dbhost} and name='xvdl'))
sources.name: telegraf-readio

sources.query: rate(ts(telegraf.diskio.writes, tag=${mirror} and not tag=eval and tag=db and source=${dbhost} and name='xvdl'))
sources.name: telegraf-writeio

sources.query: rate(ts(telegraf.diskio.read.bytes, tag=${mirror} and not tag=eval and tag=db and source=${dbhost} and name="dm-*"))
sources.name: telegraf-readbytes

sources.name: telegraf-writebytes

sources.name: telegraf-readbytes

sources.name: telegraf-writebytes

sources.name: telegraf-readbytes

sources.query: ts("telegraf.exec.enhanceio.*.stats.read.hit.pct", tag=${mirror} and not tag=eval and tag=db and source=${dbhost})

sources.query: rate(ts("telegraf.exec.enhanceio.*.stats.*", tag=${mirror} and not tag=eval and tag=db and source=${dbhost}))
sources.name: eio stats

chartSettings.plainMarkdownContent:
## FDB Basics
Identifying Common FDB
1. Look for low latency, latency can be an early indicator of cluster overall health
2. Check that storage and log queues aren't __pegged__ (stuck at, or above 1G of data in queue and not dropping)
3. Check that bytes input into the SSD cluster does not exceed the durable bytes by more than 200M for any given length of time. 
4. Work through the hosts 1-by-1 and identify possibly __stuck__ processes by inspecting the CPU Seconds / Disk IO (MEM and SSD respectively). These processes may require restarting via the `killFdbProcess.sh` script.  
5. Are proccesses flapping in and out of a cluster? It's possible that a process is still warming up, check memory utilization to ensure that a process is not still coming online and warming up (after an foundationdb conf change or restart of a process)
6. Look for Moving Data - moving data consumes a lot of CPU/IOPS and can cause delayed ingestion of indices and even (in extreme circumstances) delayed ingestion of telemetry (if SSD is pegged moving or mem tier is moving data)
7. Check that Disk IO is not flatlined on a host. This can indicate issues in AWS with reachability to EBS or degraded SSD/NVME storage.

dbhost.label: dbhost
dbhost.queryValue: collect((ts(telegraf.cpu.usage.guest, role=db and tag=${mirror} and cpu=cpu-total and not tag=retired)), (aliasSource(0, "\"*-db*-*\"")))
